snippet: Despite predictions that cheaper natural gas would generate big increases in factory payrolls, manufacturers are increasingly automated and still have two million fewer workers than in 2007.
abstract: Manufacturing is likely to fall far short of claims by industry groups that millions of new factory jobs will be created in United States because of unlocking of abundant supplies of cheap natural gas; sector has added 500,000 jobs since end of recession and value of factory output is near high, but there are two million fewer manufacturing workers in 2013 than in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Despite predictions that cheaper natural gas would generate big increases in factory payrolls, manufacturers are increasingly automated and still have two million fewer workers than in 2007.

headline.seo: Jobs Boom Built on Cheap Energy Has Yet to Appear
headline.main: Rumors of a Cheap-Energy Jobs Boom Remain Just That
